reviews.review_text: Hero Siege  is like  Diablo  stripped to its core, with some  The Binding of Isaac -like rogue elements added as spices. It's a top-down action hack 'n slash with 16-bit graphics, to be played as one of seven distinct characters, each with their own abilities and skills. During one's walk around the arena, there's gold and (some) loot to be picked up, there are (many) monsters to be slain, and every six levels, a boss (some amazingly easy, some excruciatingly difficult) awaits you. Levels and enemies are random-generated from a relatively large numer of possibilities, which guarentees a lot of differentiation. There are - very Diablo-like.. - several chapters, each chapter having 30 (!!) levels. So far, so good: the idea is sound, the graphics are fun although a bit blurred, and the gameplay - if using an Xbox 360-like controller - is as fluid as one could hope for.  But  Hero Siege  also has its share of problems. The 'rpg-light'-like leveling system, with stats- and skill-points to be distributed as one levels up, is way too unbalanced. Stats go only up by fractions of percentages, making it fairly useless to upgrade them, except maybe from level 50 or so on. Action skills are sometimes VERY powerful after a time, which will be necessary - but some are really over-the-top. Opposed to this, the amount of damage one can get while playing, is completely unpredictable. This is by itself a good thing, but some bullet-firing skulls deal such an amount of damage, that during the first six levels at least, you can die in an instant without even knowing what hit you. The graphics tend to hide these skulls sometimes, and that makes it really frustrating. It's not funny to get killed out-of-the-blue without even having a hint of what hit you. Though I have to admit, once at a certain level (certainly from 31 upwards), these devils can be survived better. Power-ups, dropped by the bosses, are really essential to survive for a longer time - but since they drop randomly as well, some games are fun because of the great assets they give, others are really disappointing since you didn't get anything worthwhile for a long time.  The good thing is that the developers are still finetuning things, and taking comments from the community into consideration, as far as I can see. That's why I give this game a thumbs-up, even if I've cried out sometimes in frustration when my poor newly-made marksman got out of the blue hit once more by a deadly bullet. What should really be implemented is a better save system: relics (power-ups) tend to get lost once I quit the game, and saving is actually only possible every act (30 levels). This game has potential, is strangely addictive (although the 152 (!!!) Steam achievements seem like impossible to get), but still has serious flaws. Luckily, the developers are still finetuning and working on it.  UPDATE (08/15)  Being curious about how the game looks and plays now, almost I year later, I started it up again, to find out some things have been improved indeed. The levelling system seems much more balanced now, there are new chapters & classes and the overall feel is more polished. However, once in-game I quickly stumbled upon the 'old problems': some enemies/bullets can still kill you instantly, and since you can't always see them coming through the mayhem this really is bothering. Overall though, I find the game to have improved significantly over the past year. The large amount of achievements has been turned down a notch or two, so that it's easier to get a reasonable number of achievements overall.   Conclusion: recommended, but not for the casual gamer looking for some easy fun

Hero siege is a 3rd person Rogue-like RPG where you fight different creatures and bosses over a variety of waves. There really isn't much more to say that that. There are a lot of different item drops, and tons of loot(potions and gold) to collect as you kill enemies and explore dungeons. There is a Nice variety of classes in the game, althought I've only played with the viking so far. I'm sure adapting to the other classes will bring further challenge. The game is a lot of fun, and at its sale price of 4.99 I would highly recommend it. I would even recommend it at its 9.99 price tag, I think the game is lots of hack and slash fun going through waves of enemies.   A few complains, but they are minor. I really wish they would have just left the voice acting out. Its absolutely terrible and not needed. I don't mean to insult anyone but the voice acting game is literally the worst I've ever heard. Hearing it at some points kind of takes away from the experience for me. I don't need to hear the viking say 'Damn, now I need to clean my axe' in a very hushed tone with little effort put into it after every boss fight. I could do without that. The other complaint is some items are just so much more valuable than others. Some items can almost guarentee a long run by themselves. I think items being more balanced would bring something more to the game.  There isn't much to say, but I do recommend this game because while the combat is simple, it still feels good and substantial. Pick this up if you're a fan of RPG's or just simple rouglelikes, you'll have a good time for at least a few hours, which is well worth the price tag.  UPDATE: Apparently people are experiencing insta-death moments and game breaking bugs. I have not experienced this but I will keep this in this review to warn you until there is a patch put out that fixes these problems for most people.  Pros: -Fun combat -Loads of enemy types -Fun boss fights, if not a bit easy sometimes -Lots of waves to go through -Plenty of classes -LOOT!  Cons: -Voice acting -Clunky interface -Imbalanced items

Getting a pair of boots at level 24 that I didn't receive a single upgrade for until level 120 or so.  Same with weapon, the best weapon I found until level 109 was a level 35 one.  The screen is absolutely cluttered with effects and you have no idea what will or will not kill you.  Traps and MANY monster effects deal % of your HP in damage, as such there's almost no point in getting HP or damage reduction.  Putting out stat points makes no difference above level 10 or so, because the majority of it will come from temporary effects, and by most, I mean 99% of it.  The end-game feels the same as level 1 through 10. Except if you die in the end-game you might as well restart your character as your temporary items (relics) are wiped.  TL;DR version  The game is an RNGfest with no proper itemization (level 24 items might be better than 100 items of the same quality), and no point in building your character in a specific way.

I absolutely love this game, but it's a complete piece of ♥♥♥♥.  Game is extremely unbalanced, a complete nightmare from that perspective.  Character classes are mostly same-ey and undifferentiated since you only get 4 active skills and the rest are generally on proc passive skills. You'll struggle and die a lot in the beginning until you randomly happen to get a purple rarity item that literally multiplies all your stats hundredfold, and then since there's no level requirements on items you'll basically never have anything else to put in that equipment slot except for another purple with marginally better stats way down the road. There's literally one artifact that doubles your character's damage. Was breezing through the game until I died and lost it, and now I can't do enough damage to stay alive. Some levels are poorly designed and force you into tight hallways in a game that's all about dodging. Some stuff kills you instantly no matter how much health you have. Certain attacks will stun you long enough to cause everything in the map to converge on you and eat your face. Other times you find yourself breezing through bosses you kill in two hits. DLC basically just makes more levels and more enemies to fight, no new items, character options, or content except new classes to play. Game is often extremely buggy and chugs at times on my gaming desktop.  Kind of fun if you can get a friend to play with, but then you have to go through the trouble of setting up port forwarding to host an online game.  There's plenty of potential for good stuff here, but nothing in the game works the way it's supposed to. Really puts a damper on all of it. As other reviewers have noted, developers focus on putting out new DLC (which adds nothing substantial) rather than fixing the base issues with the game or finding some way to balance it. It's just one huge, hot ugly mess. Basically just a levelling/loot gathering treadmill where the treadmill keeps alternating between 90mph and 0.5mph without telling you what's going on.

Definitely worth the less than dollar I paid for it. Full price, probably not.  I'm not entirely sure what the point is. The story is quite weak. The gameplay is just wave after wave of enemies with a few bosses and dungeon instances thrown in. But every time you do an instance, the entire world regenerates when you come back out. If you wanted to dive into both of those dungeons that have appeared, you're out of luck. Maybe I just got lucky on my third guy, but I played for 3 hours straight and the game was laughably easy. It took less time to get the mini-bosses (which you encounter after every handful of waves and at the end of dungeons) down to 0 HP than it did for the game to do the death animation (they have a drawn out death animation where lightning strikes all over and an angelic choir sings and the boss goes 'AAAAAAAHHHHHHHHH!' for like 10 seconds).  The gameplay is fun, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. The 'rouge-like' aspect of it is a stretch. You just lose some of your stuff. 'With RPG Elements' means there's XP, Leveling, Skill Points, and an inventory. The inventory is confusing. The control scheme is weird and inconsistent (F is the action button? But sometimes you have to press Enter... Wat?). Um... the good stuff about it is that I sank a bunch of time into it without really feeling it very much (except for the 'too easy' bit).  It seems quite a bit of content is missing from the base game. Evidently, the DLC portions of the game are each worth at least 50% of the base game cost even though it doesn't seem like each adds 50% more game. I haven't purchased them so take that with a grain of salt. There's enough wrong with the base game that it didn't seem worth it to dish out $10 (full price) for DLC (that's more than the game!).  The multiplayer was down and I didn't want to make an account with these people, so I didn't experience that aspect of it. Maybe multiplayer is where the game really shines, but from what I played the game just wasn't compelling enough for me to want to keep giving it my time. For that reason, and because of it's faults, I can't recommend you buy it at full price.  5/10 because I want my roguelikes to kill me. And because it lacks polish where it counts (balance, core game systems, multiplayer servers...).

If you want something to play that'll pass the time or crave a game with the classic RPG feeling to it, then Hero Siege is the perfect game for you. It's, in my opinion, a fantastic little gem of a game. Gameplay wise it feels as though the developer stuffed Diablo’s more reserved brother into a blender with The Binding of Issac, and added in a pinch of Killing Floor for good measure. In more sensible terms, it’s got a great number of rogue-like and RPG elements to it. There are a number of different levels, ranging from forests to snowy tundras, deserts and many more. At the end of each of these levels you can collect random pieces of loot, or relics as they’re called, which grant you varying stats and abilities. These relics come in four different flavours; weapon enhancing ones, which, as the name suggests, enhances your weapon giving it extra powers. For example an item called the Basilisk's Tooth makes it so that you have a 2% chance to turn enemies to stone. There are also passive relics as well, which improve your character’s skills. One example is the Cactus, which periodically spawns a cactus on the nearest enemy. The third relic type is active, which, after pressing the use key, will activate the effect of the relic. The Candy Crusher, one example of an active relic, launches candy in a ring around the player that explodes on landing. And the last relic type is orbiting, which float around the player and help during fights. One example is the Almighty Fedora which rapidly shoots projectiles. All these and many more can be obtained by progressing through the game, and surviving the large waves of enemies the game throws at you. Talking about enemies, there are a large number of different types. Ranging from axe throwing skeletons to towering yeti-like beasts. Also there are several “elite” type enemies that have particular skills that happen once they die. For example creating a large laser that spins in a circle or an X shaped explosion, which both appear where the “elite” was slain. There are also a number of RPG elements in the game too. For one, there are unique skill trees for each class, providing varying passive and active abilities, depending on which class you choose out of the possible seven, or ten (depending on whether you own the DLC). They also all have their own sort of personalities and quotes as well. Graphically the game looks a lot like your typical indie, rogue-like affair. But it fits nicely. The characters are easily distinguishable from each other and the varying levels all look pixel pretty with their individual themes and settings.  Overall the game feels enjoyable to play. The classes and their skills vary enough for the game to be replayed time and time again. Not to mention the seemingly endless number of experience levels you can rack up on a single class. The enemies vary in difficultly, depending on the level, and the boss battles, for the most part, feel fairly satisfying once they eventually kick the bucket. To Conclude, I’d say that Hero Siege is worth a play, whether it’s a rogue-like or an RPG you're after, or just a quick bit of fun. It’s a satisfying game to play and well worth a go. Good Day!

Decent game overall with a lot of similarities to Binding of Isaac. Like BOI, it has you progressing from area to area defeating monsters while collecting items and coins and building your stats to eventually take on the boss for that area. It also has a fair amount of replayability as you can attempt to go through the game on harder difficulties to unlock achievements.   Unlike BOI, it lacks style and flair, as well as some sort of story or setting to hold the game together and to provide motivation to progress or some sort of end-goal to work towards. The latter is not necessarily a must-have for these types of games, but I think it certainly could have been an improvement in this case. In addition, the decision to not explain much and let you figure things out as you go along (again, like Isaac) is fine, but it has issues. The key to letting one figure things out is that  one must actually be able to figure things out . In other words, the game doesn't have to hold your hand, but it needs to be intuitive to allow this learning process to happen. Things like referring to the same stat in different ways (mana and energy) will, in general, initially lead to confusion, and gameplay elements such as an empty unexplained chest forever in your inventory (that apparently is only relevant to some unique end-game boss or something) dont mesh well with the decision to let the player figure everything out on their own.  There are a few things that I particularly like about the game. For one, I think I actually prefer the way the combat feels in Hero Siege over Binding of Isaac. The hits you land on enemies just feel a bit meatier and a bit more impactful. FIghting through waves of them can be both satisfying and addicting. It's because of this that I probably don't mind too much the grindy nature of the game (a complaint I often see). It's true that the game could use some rebalancing to avoid the need to revisit and battle through the same areas to build stats and items, but I enjoy the combat enough that it's doesn't feel too much like a chore. Building a beefed-up character, by the way, can also be quite satisfying. The other thing I like about the game is its art. I'm a sucker for well-done pixel art, and the visuals in the game are just that. It's not anything mind-blowing, but it gives the game a very clean and sharp look.  Overall, I like Hero Siege. It's not amazing, but it's fun enough that I'll probably keep playing it for a while to try to get those achievements. If you like Binding of Isaac, there's a good chance you'll enjoy this to some degree.  6/10

Hero Siege is a twin stick shooter inspired by diablo, so you get things like healing wells, dangerous magic on death etc.the levels are set up as arena hold out stages where you are supposed to fend off waves of enemies.  Here's the short version. There's a real review bellow.  Pros  Cool level design. Cool Character design. minidungeons.  Cons. bad hitboxes. VERY grindy. slow progression. boring items. boring abilities.  You level up and get 2 stat points and one ability point. there are 4 stats to choose from; strength, attack speed, armor, health, and putting one point into any of the first three stats will increase it by a fraction. this is fairly useless when enemies have health values in the hundreds, and attack values high enough to be unaffected by a 0.40 increase in your armor. The ability point is really the only thing you will care about when you level up. you can spend the point in a branching ability tree. the first tier of the tree has two options, an active, and a passive, the passives increase chances, or whatever the ability is supposed to affect, by 1 measely percent, so the obvious choice is to choose the active ability, which is pretty interesting to be fair. the downside is that this active ability is all you're going to get until you are level five. this makes the game progress very very slowly.  one of the stranger things about the game considering its inspirations, is that there are very few items to collect. loot comes along once in a great while, and your first item is likely to be uninteresting. upon beating the first boss an item spawned on a pedestal in front of the portal, it was a green double crescent blade and ot gave me a SLIGHT increase to my crit chance. the boss itself dropped a token for me that gave me a stat tradeoff attack +4 armor -2. both of these were terribly dissapointing. I killed a drake type boss, and as such i expected an item to reflect that, perhaps an item that had to do with shooting a fireball or having enemies burn the ground on death, but all i got was a change to my numbers.   probably the hardest part of the game to swallow was the awful hitbox detection. i spent a long time getting used to simply hitting enemies. everything is a 2d sprite in sort of an isometric view, which makes it inherently more difficult to judge differences between distances. This can be a nightmare when fighting spiders, which have a large sprite, but a tiny hitbox. and certain classes are particularly bad at hitting enemies, in this case namely the pirate has a hard time because her pistol shots alternate between her left and right hand, which occupy different planes which makes it more than likely you will miss half of your shots unless you're very very used to her. Melee characters are also terrible because their attack animations extend beyond their hitboxes. Compare this with the binding of isaac, it has the same 2d models and the same view, but its fairly clear where you're firing and all that good stuff.  In conclusion, play either diablo or play binding of isaac. This game wants to be both, but it doesn't do either very well. If you see the game on sale, go ahead and buy it, just know that it isnt a tight and clean experience.

This game is frequently updated by the developers based on community feedback (that's a good thing), so this review is based on version 1.0.7.1 of the game.   Hero Siege is an excellent time-killer. Twin-stick, randomly-generated, Roguelike gameplay with 5+ classes, customization, dozens of special items to find in dungeons for extra power... It scatches so many game itches for those of us who enjoy some action RPG (light RPG, mind you) fun. The basis of the game is fighting off wave after wave of enemies, leveling up as you do so and obtaining items of power (relics) on a periodic basis. This game screams for a gamepad; you move in eight directions and shoot in four independent directions, while also activating items, allocating stats at level and buying from shops. I don't want to imagine doing that on a keyboard.  Like a true Roguelike, there's no telling what you'll get with each area. Maps are generated randomly; you might be under constant assault by traps (which you can lure monsters into), have a maze of trees to navigare through, find a bounty of loot chests, or all sorts of other scenarios. There are over 100 relics right now to find in the game, and each provides either a significant stat boost or a special ability to your character. It's complete luck of the draw what you get, and the developers were gutsy enough to put in some truly unbalanced items, such as relics that give you the ability to fly over open air and water, staying completely out of the range of many enemies. No game played is a waste; if you die, you'll lose all the relics you've collected, but can restart with all the levels your character has amassed (except in the perma-death Hardcore mode.)  Miniboss and legendary versions of regular enemies show up on a regular basis and every sixth wave, you'll fight a boss creature; success takes you to a new area (and often rewards you with a relic.) There are four 'Acts' to the game, with apparently more to come, and 5 classes to try out and level up, also apparently with more to come. The game supports some sort of local multiplayer right now, but I have only done single-player mode. I can imagine that getting 2-4 people going on the same game would be a hilarious blast.  The bottom line is that there's a lot of variety in this little title. The repetitve wipe-em-out nature of the game might not be for everyone, but I've already put in 12+ hours on a single class type, and that's more 'fun' time than I've gotten out of many AAA titles at three times the price or more.

The gameplay, however...when others have mentioned it's frustrating, they're not kidding. And it's not the kind of frustrating that really keeps you coming back, it's just annoying and, after a point, boring. The game boasts random, different levels, but I just got the same exact level over and over again, with no differences that I could detect. The bosses are cheap in a boring way, the experience is just...boring. It's boring and frustrating, which are two things that I don't look for in games.  Maybe if I enjoyed this genre more, I'd really be into this one, but it doesn't make any impression but a bad one with me. I didn't want it to hold my hand, but it not only didn't hold my hand, it tossed me in with no explanations as to anything. While that can be fine for some, a lack of explanation on essential features like skills and powers really is inexcusable; all you have is an icon, which doesn't really illustrate what it's for. So setting skills is hit or miss...mostly miss, because you don't really know what's going to be useful.  And speaking of hits, the hit detection in this game is really questionable. Oh, something's in your general vicinity! I guess it does damage to you. Oh wait, there's something random that appeared from nowhere! Guess you're dead, time to start the whole level over again. Oh, fun. I adore retreading well-tread paths. Especially when I've done it a dozen times before. But it doesn't really even make encounters exciting or fun, just irritating because you do not, in any way, have the ability to take on any and every foe, but of course they have the capability of steamrolling you, or at least whittling you down until you're so bored you either make a crucial error or just quit the game altogether.  There's also attempts at 'bullet hell' type scenarios, which only artificially ramp up the game's difficulty, usually in an annoying way, and it doesn't really mesh well with the rest of the game. The whole experience seems to be a 'trying too hard' one desperately tossing in artificial ways of ramping up difficulty without actual thought given to how to make the game more fun and enjoyable. Because it's not. It's the opposite of fun.   If you're into the dual-stick shooter type games, check it out. Maybe you'll enjoy it. But honestly I can't really recommend this to anyone. Hero Siege is a pure grind for skills and upgrades RPG with rogue like randomness. You play on a battlefield that is about 12 times larger than the screen, each time the locations of elements are randomized and there are a few things you can count on but the rest is randomized. Ever now and again you will find a dungeon or keep which forces the camera closer to your character giving you linear levels with puzzles and boss battles to break up the monotany, these can vary greatly in difficulty, but always worth the risk unless you get those rare super difficult ones.  This game is addicting and well thought out, but there are problems. The randomness lends itself to you dying for very stupid reasons, like triggering a laser blast that drains your health in a few ticks of the game time while against a tree or simply grabbing a potion at the wrong time. No game is perfect, but this game is a little more varied than I am used to and comes with a few bugs that don't break the game, but should be very easy for the developer to fix.  - Clothing options don't actually show the characters you have assigned to the slots - Clothing options reset every time you use them - Some stats don't add up correctly when you have multiple items (vague but it seems to happen ever few games) - Sometimes it seems like if you have a skill that fires 5% of the time, it will fire 5 times in a row for every 100 shots... weird.  Some of the characters are kind of broken when compared to the others like the viking and the necromancer.  The Viking's skills are geared towards charging enemies, but running at them might be a death sentence. Some bosses are near impossible to beat with the viking as he has no long range attacks. Giving him regeneration or the ability to redirect damage would fix him in some respect, but right now, he is about the worst character.  The Necromancer's minions fall off the screen often... always when you don't need it. Almost impossible for the necromancer to beat some dungeons because of this.  The rest of the characters are fine, but those two need the help of a coop partner, which brings this game up several notches in enjoyment.  There are problems, but this is a great game to just have fun with someone else and grind. The fun is finite, but for $6 it is worth it. Grab a friend and two controllers and start slaying monsters in mass. You can amp your characters to the point you are destroying everything on the screen with little effort, but the curveballs this game throws at you always keep you on your toes. DO NOT DRINK POTIONS YOU DIDN'T BUY ON YOUR OWN!!!

Hero Siege is a good game and I think there are some good elements in its style and play but I am only *just* giving it a thumbs up and you'll see why later.  To begin with it seems fairly straight forward and the controls are extremely similar to those in 'The Binding Of Isaac'. You go around, you kill stuff and you die. A lot.A whole damn lot. It is a nice challenge to begin with and when you win you feel like a boss. When you lose, you lose everything except your experience/level. This gets frustrating and the fact that when you open the shop the game doesn't pause just adds to my 'Rage-o-meter of screw you game'. Despite these annoying flaws the key gameplay remains acceptable.  I quite enjoy the occasional spawning of mini-boss monsters and it adds a nice touch that traps are littered around for you to kill enemies with. One problem though. These traps can just as easily kill you and when they hit you, it hurts. It REAAAALLLY hurts! This is incredibly annoying and has resulted in me beating many a boss just to have a flying spiky testicle of doom shoved in my face. Annoying really.  The bosses are varied but most are really too easy to begin with. When you beat the boss (and don't get 'testicled' to death) you can gain a power up or item, much like in 'The Binding of Isaac'. These range from overpowered hamburgers to davinci style missile shooters. Some are excellent ideas with a cool graphic style. Some are absolute ♥♥♥♥.  The classes are rather badly composed with four currently available and the only ones that are any good are those that have ranged attacks. The other ones are useless because nearly ALL the enemies have ranged attacks and more than one of the bosses can nigh insta-kill you with his attacks which are close range whereas with a ranged character you can sit-back, get popcorn and smash the boss' face in.  Despite all this I really enjoy playing this game but only in short bursts. It can be an incredibly fun game with okay music and good gameplay mechanics but if you rage easily or didn't like 'The Binding of Isaac' it really isn't worth your time. I will go straight to the point. If you want a more detailed analysis, read further.  Pros: Extremely Rewarding/Satisfying Gameplay TONS of Replayability Challenging Difficulty Wide Character-Customization 2-Player Same Screen  Cons: Repetitive Music Character Movement - At times, especially when completing  quests, character movement may feel slow in contrast to the size of the map. These can be fixed by drinking potions though. Multiplayer Servers - Multiplayer is in Beta, so don't judge heavily on this analysis. Sometimes the servers can go down.  Interface: Simple, In-Game however is a bit tricky to understand, but nothing too hard to grasp. Graphics: Old school 2D 8-bit. Theme: Dark cult, 'Binding of Isaac'-like. Music: Soundtrack goes very well with the theme of the game however at times may seem quite repetitive. Difficulty: Hard, yet very rewarding. Gameplay: A LOT OF FUN, hours of replayability, wide arsenal of characters, every playthrough is different than the last. DLC: The DLC is excellent, however you do not need it to play the game, as it is not a free-to-play.   -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  I picked up this game while it was on sale and thought I'd give it a try. By far one of the best and most addicting games I've played in a while. This game has similar concepts as 'The Binding of Isaac' in which you pick up 'Relics' (Power-Ups) to alter the game, some better than others. The skills each character has really represents their style, no 2 characters are similar. Speaking of characters, you can customize them with all sorts of reminiscent features from other more bigger-title games, from Twisted Metal, to Halo, to Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance, and many other titles.  Hero Siege handles gold as a currency however it features a special type that allows you to purchase customizable features. You don't have to worry about spending any real money to acquire 'Crystals' though. Once you buy the game there isn't any more money you have to spend to unlock anything, asides DLC. The crystals are harder and slower to acquire, thus adding to the grind-like game. But the rate in which you get these seems just right, you are rewarded every time you do something big like clear a dungeon or defeat a boss.  In conclusion I absolutely love this game and recommend it to anyone who enjoys: Diablo 3 The Binding of Isaac Realm of the Mad God Rogue Legacy  You will find that this game, although having similar traits to the games listed above, stands out on its own.

When you first make a character in Hero Siege and begin on Act I, you'll find it difficult. You'll find the game frustrating. But, once you overcome the restlessness that comes along with starting a new game and find yourself settled with the game, prepare to become fully infatutated with Hero Siege. Hero Siege has a lot of great points, as well as bad, which you can easily find out either by reading reviews on the game or buying it and finding out wether you dislike/like the game there. Don't let the reviews sway your mind to only take one look at the game and either buy or ignore the game. See for yourself thoroughly, wether or not you want the game, because Hero Siege isn't your average game.  As I said before, Hero Siege has its good and bad points, the things that determine its quality. Some good things about Hero Siege is that it twists RPG elements in a good way. For example, normally in quests for RPGs, you'd have to travel through multiple environments, defeat a couple of enemies, or retrieve something important to the quest giver in order to receive a reward that you already knew you'd get (for the most part). But, in Hero Siege, you'll never know what you'll get. Maybe some new armour, maybe a buttload of coins. (I find the mystery in that enticing.) Your reward varies, wether or not you did something difficult. Adding on to this, a lot of quests in RPGs have you running around and traversing multiple stages/environments, which again, is different from Hero Siege, where your quest and everything needed to fulfill it is right on one screen from your quest-giver to your objective(s) in the quest.  As I said before, though, Hero Siege also has bad things about it. For example, it's hard to get into at the start, as I said before. Trying to play with friends is a pain, and if you run on a toaster and find out that the game only allows the FPS to go up to 60, you'd die by the pain that is lag. As well as the fact of all the bugs that involve relics and the stages that can knock you into a gate that you will never be able to leave.  But y'know, Hero Siege is a perfectly good hack 'n slash in my opinion, though I have almost no experience with games like these outside of the game itself. Besides, all these reasons that represent Hero Siege's 'quality' doesn't really matter all that much because it doesn't matter wether in some peoples' eyes it's a good game or not. What you think of the game is what matters. I recommend this game because that shows what I think of Hero Siege.

This game has suprised me. It has elements of rougelikes, twin-stick shooters, and RPGs. I initially bought it when it was on sale over at  Humblebundle.com  for something like a dollar or two. I thought, 'hey this will be a good hour or so' then 5 hours later I realised that this game had me hooked. Once the DLC for Act V and the Samurai came out I happily paid the $6 for it. This game is well worth that and even more.  The art style is charming and I've found that I really enjoy the asthetic of the monsters, player models, and all the effects. The UI leaves something to be desired though. These guys are constantly updating things and they listen to player feedback. Although, they can get a bit defensive at times. There are a few issues which make it a little bit frustrating at times. For instance if you view a relic that you don't want inbetween waves you have to push B (or the keyboard equivalant) to discard it. This will automatically trigger the next wave since the discard relic and start next wave buttons are one in the same. The reason this is annoying is because if there was a dungeon or crypt that you wanted to visit between waves, well, that's closed until the next wave now. All-in-all this is only a minor concern.  The game is completely addictive. Each run is over once you die but you level you character and become more powerful and your next run is even better than the last. As with many games with rouge-lite elements you will amass items in order to make your toon more powerful over the course of the run. This is reminiscent of The Binding of Issac. One run might not be very powerful and you might die early on, and the next run you'll be a god smashing through hoards of mobs with righteous vengeance! The addtion of online co-op and the inclusion of local co-op just enhance this experience. However, a word of caution; the MP aspect of the game is currently in a buggy state. While the devs are constantly working to fix it, it would seem that they are having a bit of trouble in that department. None-the-less, I still highly recommend this game.

Hero Siege is kinda like those WC3 Hero Defense custom maps back in the day--it's just about running around grinding waves of enemies until you hit a boss. This game is pretty much a portmanteau of Diablo 3 and Binding of Isaac gameplay.  This game is really addicting and has the potential to be great, but there are a few glaring issues holding it back.  The first--going back to where I said it's like Diablo 3, this game has an unhealthy obsession with Blizzard crap. Expect to encounter Diablo/Warcraft references (including Acolyte quotes and a Frostmourne item) which are amusing at first but become tiresome quickly.  The second is the Diablo 3-like difficulty scaling. The game rips off their elite/boss system in which dead bosses sometimes shoot stuff at you after they're dead. One of these is a giant spinning laser which is obviously taken straight from D3. My main contention is not that the ripoffs ruin the game, but that it introduces the same problem that D3 had--you can go multiple levels without taking too much damage, and then you get a spinning laser put right on top of you in a hallway, or some super-damaging projectile hidden amongst the hundreds of other projectiles littering the screen and die immediately, sometimes without knowing what caused it (and allocating your stats defensively does not mitigate this at all). In this way the game is unbalanced because the game will be a walk in the park for 30 minutes straight and then have a massive difficulty spike for a few seconds which kills you because your reactions are only human.  The third is the stat system. Str and Dex (or was is Speed? whatever the equivalent was) are completely useless and only increase the stats by the smallest possible fraction. As a result, builds that rely on attack speed or attack damage are useless, and subsequently, so are 50% of the items in the game that increase these stats. Thus the success of a character build invariably falls on 'whose flat-damage abilities scale the best?' (Hint: it's probably Pyromancer.)   So, those are the main issues. Other than that, the awful voice acting contributes a lot to the annoyance factor of the game. I'd have to guess that the devs decided to do the voices themselves--which was a bad decision considering their broken English (they're from Finland). The soliloquies are stupid too ('Are you losing it? I am not.' 'It's good to be on this side of the bow.').  I've sunk a decent amount of hours into this game (30+ at this time of writing), so the game was still a lot of fun despite my complaints. I think I got to Nightmare mode and then stopped because of all the random unavoidable deaths. I don't think I will be spending much more time playing this game, unless they hopefully fix some of these problems with the upcoming expansion. Overall I still definitely recommend this game for a lot of hours of fun (even more so with co-op) especially given its low price.  TL;DR: Devs are obsessed with Blizzard games. Insane difficulty spikes. Broken stat system. Still a fun co-op experience for many hours.  EDIT: They added a mana management system that sucks all the fun out of the game. I don't recommend this anymore.
